While some kids were dreaming about exploring the unreached wanders of space, during my childhood, I was amazed by the fact that the depths of the ocean were not given as much interest. I always considered the ocean to be a space within Earth—vast, unexplored, so close—yet so far. The video I watched took me back to my childhood fantasies while providing some curious details about biology, in particular, the topic of evolution. It was a bewildering experience to contemplate how life on Earth was able to adjust to the harshest of conditions, such as those present at the bottom of the ocean. Evolution resulted in the creation of truly breathtaking creatures ready to survive in an unnormal environment that, at first glance, shouldn't be habitable at all. Interestingly enough, this chain of thoughts took me back to space and left me wondering—if life can exist in the depths of the ocean, why can't it exist in the vastness of space?

But the "cars on top of you" (or eventually the elephants) is misleading, as the pressure is isostatic, i.e. not just "on top of you," but coming at you from all possible directions. There is a world of complications with that of course. (Even if you breathe compressed gas, as they do up to 300 m deep, it will still lead to all kinds of complications. I have a head cannon for the ocean- I like to think there’s a gigantic cave under the deepest part of the ocean where life is thriving and there’s a huge monster like humanoid fish like creature. I know your thinking of mermaids, but no. This is the, bellower. A distant relative of the siren. It sleeps in the cavern but when it’s sleep is disturbed, it will wake up and destroy the planet. One singular cry from it in it’s native cave could create a tsunami so big I could wipe out half of Africa. The bellower is said to only wake on certain occasions. For example, when there is more plastic in the ocean than fish. Or when president trump goes swimming. If the bellower wakes and we’ve completely cleaned out the ocean it will shrink to a smaller size to fit in with the wildlife and emerge from the cave. It will eventually wake. Every 10,000 years or so it wakes up and checks on it’s oceans. So next time you see plastic on the beach, pick it up and put it in it’s rightful place. We all have to pitch in to have peace with the bellower.

One thing you forgot to mention that's incredibly interesting is brine pools. Brine pools are literal lakes below the sea. They contain water with an extremly high salinity and actual have a distinct surface towards the ocean. Brine pools are so incredibly saline that most fish that enter them die almost immedietly. Except hagfish. Hagfish don't give a flying fuck about the salinity of the brine pool and use them as personal hiding spots. But the most interesting thing about brine pools is that each and every one of them has a unique composition and a unique fauna of microorganisms that exist only at that particular brine pool.

I wonder if Europa have marine snow. If so, is it much less due to an glacier crust on the surface? Is underneath surface of the ice crust full of simple and or complex life? Is there different types of liquid and thus different creatures divided into different niches (ex: salt brine pool vs regular ocean water.) And without mass extinction events, its ocean creatures would have had more time to evolve than ours. Does convergence evolution work interplanetary if the same evolutionary forces exists?

Imagine an intelligent civilization having evolved under these depths.
They would think "the sky" is the dark infinite ocean.
Taking them up to the surface, and showing them the brilliance of the sun, would be like that crazy guy in the movie Sunshine just being utterly obliterated, physically and psychologically, upon seeing the power.

I mean just imagine.. We're so narrowminded, even when we think we are open minded about other life in the universe.
But its completely possible that there are intelligent lifeforms out there that has NEVER seen the "sky" of their planet, either due to them being in the ocean or in subterranean cavern systems without any clear path "out".

Just imagine what kind of society they would have, with no awareness of the "outside".
And the shock they would feel upon the revelation of the surface, not to mention space outside their planet.
(Just because they havent developed sufficent seismic sensors to figure out there's a "surface" up above, wouldnt mean they are any less intelligent that we were during the roman age).

Summary:

1*Bioluminesence is used by 90% of all sea creatures.
2*Bioluminesence uses are camoflage, to send signals to others,to confuse,and scare attackers, and hunt.
3*Siphonophores live 700 meters down in the sea,they can be 50 meters in length,but is only as wide as a broomstick,they use bright-red, and blue lights to hunt.
4*Siphonophores use tentacles with toxic needles that will kill anything that gets to close.
5*Most animals that live at the bottom of the sea eat ''Marine snow'',which is dead plant ,animal,and fecal matter.
6*The Titanic sunk below 3800 meters.

Lesson learned: Never trust USPS
Although my package started as UPS, it was switched to USPS, then back to UPS, and USPS again. I didn't even know USPS has an awful service, since it was my first time shipping from overseas, and I didn't know my package would be transferred from UPS to USPS.

The biomass graphic was slightly misleading. Ocean biomass is so much smaller not because there are less fish than cows. It has to do with the sheer biomass of forests. Forests take time to grow and provide fruit or leaves that are eaten while the trees survive.  Plankton is in sharp contrast and  can reproduce rapidly while also being consumed rapidly. While low trophic levels account for most of the terrestrial biomass the opposite is often true for marine biomass.

I don't know if anyone else has commented this, but I feel necessary to point out that vampyromorphs live in the minimum oxygen zone (which its depth range interval is quite variable in different regions), unlike the active predators depicted afterwards. May be it was too much to spend even more time explaining what the minimum oxygen zone is (personally, I have had a hard time trying to explain it to students or even colleagues... and may be it's even harder to explain why oxygen concentration may peak again near to its maximum when approaching the abyssal plains).


Even so, I would like to take the opportunity to infinitely thank you. Your videos have made me quite happy and I don't cease to find them stimulating. I really appreciate your endeavor providing accurate as well as entertaining science content. I find it quite awesome and reinvigorating in my personal pursue trying to understand and share what the universe around us is all about. In more than several occasions, I've made use of your content as an aid while teaching high school students in different science subjects and also as recreational material to enjoy with friends. One of my favourite anecdotes regarding sharing your videos was when I let students from one of my past groups decide which video from your channel they wanted to see for an activity, and one of them chose the one titled "Optimistic nihilism"; when she told me she found it extremely beautiful and that she almost cried because of it, I responded that I actually did the first time I saw it.


Thank you again. I wish you the best and not just because I'm expecting more of your delightful content; you make the world a better place for human beings.

What astounds me about movement towards/against gravity is how we have to use units that are a mouthfull because otherwise our brain wouldn't register the extremes it reaches.

Example: On this video we reach "Eleven thousand meters" towards the bottom of the sea, that's just 11Km. An average human can run that distance in about 30 to 60 minutes without losing much breath, but we just have to be moving "parallel" (or horizontally, or around??,) gravity, instead of towards it.

Anoher example is the space limit, its about 30 Km "and some change" going up, but flip it "horizontally" and it's just the commute distance I do every day going to work in about 30 minutes.

Those distances seem so close, so within reach, but it's so hard AND dangerous to go in those directions without proper equipment and precautions it's so unbelieavable.

Fascinating but also a little depressing: "It's probably unlikely that we'll find a new deepest point in an entirely different part of the world. Bathymetry, the science of underwater topography, has long been using sophisticated sonar equipment to create digital maps of underwater terrain. Sonar beams sent to the ocean floor are updated many times per second, and verified by Global Positioning Satellites. These maps clearly indicate the Mariana Trench as the deepest of its kind, and so far the Challenger Deep is its lowest measured point. Chances are, if the depth or the location of the world's deepest point ever does change, it won't be by much."

This shit is really amazing whenever you realize that while we know what our forests and rain forests and swamps are all like, we really also don't know fucking shit about them. We know they're there, we've gone in and went "Oh look that's an animal, okay let's right down what it looks like" then that's that. We don't know anything about them past that. We don't know their habits, what symbiotic relationships they have, how the ecosystems function. On top of that we don't know anything about rain forests whenever you consider and realize that there's more species of plants and animals than in a kilometer of rain forest than the entire continent of Europe.

Not sure if you're aware of it from the intro, but there are places we (the global community we) have not been.  There's a few remote tribes in the rainforests in and around Peru who I've generally heard called "the uncontacted."  They're tribes that the Spanish and Portuguese never found back in the day, and have seemingly never had any contact with the rest of humanity since  those early colonial times.  These days, there are pretty strict laws forbidding anyone contacting them in any way, even leaving supplies out for them during bad years, because of the fear that they might never have come into contact with global diseases.  (With death tolls from the first contact plagues that swept through the Americas generally estimated around 90% of the population, that's something that should be avoided.)  Anthropologists occasionally get permits to go to those areas and do some long range studying, but even that's kept to a minimum.

10,000 meters sounds super deep, but then you realize that that's just 10 km, not even seven miles. Horizontally on land, that's within walking distance within a couple hours, but turn that distance on its side and it becomes so inaccessible. A few months ago, there was a Sixty Symbols video about how close outer space is - but that was about 80 to 100 km (so New York City is closer to space than it is to Philadelphia). The bottom of the ocean is closer still by a factor of 8 or 10.

I guess I'm weird, but I felt strangely charmed by the idea of that plastic bag down there in the remotest place on earth. I wonder from where it came from, when it was taken out and handled to a customer, to carry what purchase, how many times it changed hands before being discarded, and who was the last human that touched it. To think that something so mundane, laying around our houses could end up in such an extraordinary place, tickles my fantasy... And yes I know it's terrible for the environment, a striking symbol of human hubris and all that jazz. Still, I find it fascinating.

Is it possible that deep sea gigantism is caused because of a relative lack of predators in the deep sea? Predators might prefer larger prey because it means more energy return on the energy spent hunting (humans - for example - are happy with catching big fish but disappointed with small ones). The large surface level creatures were eaten, so evolution tended towards smaller creatures because they're the ones who survived. However, this never occurred In the deep sea.

Using the "its like XXXX number of things on top of you" is the dumbest way to explain pressure because it only applies if there is no internal equalization... Scuba divers do not feel that pressure because it does not exist, the body acclimates to the pressure by increasing the internal pressure relative to the outside. Those animals at the bottom are not under 1500 PSI "crushing them" any more than we are being crushed by 15 PSI standing on the beach; meaning, standing at sea level is like being crushed by 40,000 lbs. There is no crushing or pressure when both sides are equal.

Some say it's a hostile place inhabitated by the strangest creatures, others that it's a prison, for the most dangerous outcasts. But the only way of ever finding out, is to go there, and see for yourself

Am I the onlyone that found that only 2% of the total biomass exist in the ocean sounds wrong?... i m reading the source and they admit to having bias in their estimations:

"The certainty of the estimate is linked to the amount of sampling on which the estimate is based. Notable locations in which sampling is scarce are the deep ocean (usually deeper than 200 m) and deep layers of soil (usually deeper than 1 m). For some organisms, such as annelids and marine protists and arthropods, most estimates neglect these environments, thus underestimating the actual biomass. Sampling can be biased toward places that have high abundance and diversity of wildlife. Relying on data with such sampling bias can cause overestimation of the actual biomass of a taxon."

They calculate biomass not by total weight but by amount of Carbon that could be also be messing with intuition. I found hard to believe that such a bast and diverse ecosystem can exist with so little biomass in it. Sadly I m not good at math so i can t try to found an answer in their estimates.

Subnautica fans: Am I a joke to you?

Over 90% of the species native to this enviornment use bioluminesence...

I am hesitant to accept this, as I doubt we've mapped all creatures at this deapth and obviously we'd find the ones who litterally glow first.

Please note that surface corals are not plants instead being animals that have formed a symbiotic relationship with algae, while you never explicitly say they are you do allow that mistaken conclusion to be drawn as many people are shockingly still confused on that.


Regarding the oceans it should be noted that away from the continental shelves or points of nutrient upwelling things are quite desolate even at the surface with phytoplankton even turning to consuming other phytoplankton to survive. Over fishing is such a horrendous problem as sonar instrumentation has given us the ability to commit commercial genocide on sea life as they have no where to run or hide against trawling nets and radar and the loss of an individual is comparable to the loss of entire peoples in terms of the consequences when things live so slowly that they started their lives when our great great great great great great grandparents had yet to be born.


And we must be wary of the potential risks harvest of manganese nodules and other forms of deep sea exploitation as among deep sea creatures many don't reach sexual maturity for hundreds of years while living for thousands of years only to be destroyed by short sighted greedy humans in an instant. A Greenland shark takes over 500 years to reach sexual maturity and some corals down there are over 20,000 years old. We have no business down there aside from research and even scientists need to be more careful about how they do research since every sample harvest is unsustainable when the organisms in question were born before the dawn of civilization and where microbes take years to double their populations.


The deep sea and subterranean biospheres are alien to us as they live at incomprehensibly long timescales in the harshest conditions and environments possible. Vertebrates like us are alien to these realms evolving in the shallow coves of the Paleozoic spoiled by the riches of the sun we must not treat these deep dark sunless realms as we do the surface realm for damage done there will last millennia as virulent scars on our world.

This is more scientific than any game theory ever made. But I feel like these "Deep Sea" explaining videos are getting a bit stale. It's the same explanation in almost every video. Yes, I know the Mariana Trench is the lowest point we've explored in the dark ocean, and that the Sperm Whale and Giant Squid (or Colossal Squid) fight whenever the Sperm Whale tries to look for food to feed it's young. I've heard it over a hundred times by now. I know there isn't much to talk about anyway because we haven't discovered much still, but you could at least say something that not many people would even think to say. Maybe give your own opinions about it? Or telling us how these dark depths started out as far back as the dinosaurs? Or even try and use data we have today to maybe think about and predict what the deep sea could turn into in the far future? I'm not saying you should just rewrite everything that's been noted about the deep sea, but I'd really appreciate it if you could spice things up. Too many people say the same thing, and too many times I've been reminded of it. Although, that little Street Sharks tease at the end with the "20% off" sign was kind of a nice touch, since somebody talked about them a couple days ago.

As a human biologist, I cannot emphasise enough how important the discovery of new organisms in the sea is. To give you an example, studies on the jellyfish Aequorea victoria has enabled us to isolate the green fluorescent protein (GFP), which, as the name suggests, exhibits bright green fluorescence. Today, we wildly fuse GFP with other proteins in order to make them visible and observe processes in cells. GFP is so wildly used today that its discovery has been awarded with the 2008 Nobel Prize in Chemistry (would love to make a video about the applications of this bright protein). Who knows what else we could find in the deep sea? Feel free to ask anything about that topic (or stem cells, since I am conducting research in this field)!
